abstract.p: Zachary Selden letter contends that US needs sustained commitment to detecting and neutralizing biological weapons

block.p: Richard Preston (Op-Ed, Nov. 7) is correct in that biological weapons are one of the most significant security threats we face today. But sophisticated, genetically engineered agents are not the most immediate concern; catastrophic carnage can be caused by low-technology biological weapons. Anthrax, for example, can be produced in quantities to wipe out an entire city with minimal expertise and equipment.

Richard Preston (Op-Ed, Nov. 7) is correct in that biological weapons are one of the most significant security threats we face today. But sophisticated, genetically engineered agents are not the most immediate concern; catastrophic carnage can be caused by low-technology biological weapons. Anthrax, for example, can be produced in quantities to wipe out an entire city with minimal expertise and equipment.

Terrorists and rogue states are more likely to employ these simple technologies. The United States does indeed need a sustained commitment to detecting and neutralizing biological weapons, but we should focus on the simplest and most deadly forms.
The writer is a policy associate with Business Executives for National Security.
